etymologies: mid 17th century: from Latin incubat- ‘lain on’, from the verb incubare, from in- ‘upon’ + cubare ‘to lie’

definitions: (of a bird) sit on (eggs) in order to keep them warm and bring them to hatching.
shortDefinitions: sit on eggs to hatch them

definitions: (especially in a laboratory) keep (eggs, cells, bacteria, embryos, etc.) at a suitable temperature so that they develop

examples.text: the samples were incubated at 80°C for three minutes

shortDefinitions: keep at right temperature to develop

definitions: have an infectious disease developing inside one before symptoms appear

examples.text: the possibility that she was incubating early syphilis

definitions: develop slowly without outward or perceptible signs

examples.text: unfortunately the BSE bug incubates for around three years
